intro: Pentalophus longiflorus, commonly known as the long-flowered pentalophus, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is native to southern Africa, where it typically grows in moist, open habitats such as grasslands and forest margins. The plant features slender, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves with a distinctive, fragrant scent. Its flowers are small, white to pale yellow, and arranged in compound umbels, which attract various pollinators. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation efforts.
